story:
Who we are   

Ektoras Binikos, mixologist and artist; Simon Jutras, commercial photographer and designer of interiors & furniture.

Together we will operate Sugar Monk (in West Harlem, NYC), an intimate venue where art, mixology, and alchemy will combine to transcend the senses and elate the most discriminating palates. Our creative and entrepreneurial backgrounds, enhanced by two decades of immersion in New York's art community, have so far resulted in award-winning mixology programs for some of NYC's finest establishments, and a successful photography & design portfolio with many notable clients. This is a very special moment in Harlem's history, and the perfect time to open Sugar Monk.


                                                               William Blake cocktail

Your help is crucial to the realization of our project. Your contributions will defray the initial costs related to opening our space and the buzz from this campaign will propel further funding.

Our goals and how you can help

In New York City, West Harlem is at this moment the most exciting place to open our cocktail lounge - a dream we’ve entertained for a long time. With many years of experience in the New York bar & restaurant world, we are ready to open a place of our very own. In fact, we have found our ideal space at the heart of West Harlem and are currently negotiating the lease.  Now is the perfect time to jump wholeheartedly into this thrilling venture.  

Your help is crucial to the realization of this project. We aim to raise approximately $50,000 to cover legal fees, liquor license, design, lease acquisition & security deposit, architect’s fee, and construction permits; a successful campaign and global response will create a terrific buzz to excite investors and complete our funding.

We thank you in advance for your help – we appreciate the confidence you have placed in us. Here's to creating art in a glass!

                                       Rebecca Horn cocktail - detail  (The Artist's Cup)

Where the money will go

To better understand how your contributions will be used, we have itemized our expenses below.

                      

Your contributions will be rewarded with some exciting gifts!

                                               



The Impact

Harlem today is culturally richer, more diverse and hip than ever before – its neighborhoods never so sought-after by visitors since the Harlem Renaissance. This is Harlem's comeback, full of flavors and surprises.

We have a vision of a forward-thinking and sophisticated place where neighborhood residents, cocktail aficionados, foreign visitors, and the arts community will all gather. At Sugar Monk, art will meet mixology.

Binikos’ ingenious art cocktails are created from the most unusual elements and thrill the most discerning palates. The drinks will be made with the freshest ingredients, the finest spirits, and an array of artisanal bitters, infusions, and extracts, all beautifully presented.

The rich sensory experience of exquisite cocktails and warm, splendid art-filled surroundings with eclectic music will assure a magical evening. 

We are very excited to join Harlem’s vibrant and historical community alongside local legends such as The Apollo Theater, Studio Museum of Harlem, Minton's, Sylvia’s, and The Schomburg Center. Harlem is a unique and culturally rich neighborhood and we are honored to be a part of it, as both residents and business owners.

More About Us

Master mixologist Ektoras Binikos has been head mixologist at the 3-star restaurants Aureole and Oceana, and at the renowned Michael’s New York.  Most recently, he was the mixologist and managing partner at the 2ndFloor on Clinton, an exclusive cocktail lounge on Manhattan's Lower East Side.  His unique talents and managerial skills have ensured a solid track record of success for the past 3 years.

                           

2ndFloor on Clinton is already famous – it features in countless guide books worldwide and has earned great reviews from Yelp,Google and Foursquare. It is listed as one of New York's Best Speakeasy Bars by the Business Insider, the Thrillist, and Yelp. 

                                               

(The ownership of the building has recently changed and 2nd Floor on Clinton  closed on July 29, 2015)                                              

             

Binikos has always been at the forefront of mixology and has won numerous awards. He has created cocktails to raise funds for charity events as diverse as HURRICANE KATRINA, an NYC AIDS benefit for Rwandan children and THE AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY. His cocktails have also helped fund the MILLAY COLONY OF THE ARTS in Austerlitz, NY, the SPENCERTOWN ACADEMY FOR THE ARTS in Spencertown, NY, and the STEEL YARD ART COLONY in Rhode Island. In 2011 he founded ART & SPIRIT MIXOLOGY, a company focusing on fine mixology, restaurant consulting, brand development & alignment, mixology seminars, and custom-designed specialty cocktails for corporate & private events.

Binikos has been featured in several publications, including NY Magazine, Time Out NY, The Daily News, The San Francisco Chronicles, Wine Enthusiasts, Village Voice, Manhattan Magazine, and Paper Magazine. 

                                                                    

He strongly believes that mixology is alchemy, the mysterious process by which inspiration is transmuted into a liquid creation. It is the chemistry of the most subtle kind which gives the mixologist the ability to transform base spirits into noble elixirs of life.

                                                                                                                                 

                                                                        

In February of 2007, world-renowned performance artist MARINA ABRAMOVIC and the New York GUGGENHEIM MUSEUM commissioned Binikos to create a birthday cocktail for Abramovic’s 60th Birthday Celebration Gala at the museum.


LIQUID HYMNS TO THE POIGNANT MUSIC OF J.S.BACH

On June 27th 2012, he collaborated with the acclaimed Icelandic violinist Hlif Sigurjons in a live performance at the 2nd Floor on Clinton. During Sigurjóns’ candlelight performance of the seminal Partita II in D minor for solo violin, Binikos served the audience five unusual spirited infusions, each corresponding to a particular movement of the piece. The alchemical potions were spring-water based, infused with herbs, bark, extracts, spices, dry berries, leaves, roots, tree resin, alcoholic spirits, and bitters. Binikos' inspiration for these infusions came from his narrative interpretation of the movements as well as his emotional response to each.

​In 2012 Binikos was commissioned by Absolut vodka to create a cocktail,The Absolut Kelly (influenced by the ideas of Joseph Beuys) for the inaugural event of the Sean Kelly Gallery in New York.

      


 

                                 Caspar David Friedrich cocktail (The Artist's Cup)


                                                  

Gary Regan, an authority in mixology, noted cocktailian and author of numerous books said: "I wish there were more bartenders like him, but that would be impossible. I am so impressed with all the thoughts that go into his creations. He's one of a kind. And we're lucky enough to be around to witness his genius."                

                                           Joseph Beuys cocktail (The Artist's Cup)

Simon Jutras has a very diverse creative background.  His keen interest in architecture & design has led him to create interiors and design furniture for numerous private clients. 

He has also been a successful New York photographer running his own company Simon Jutras Photography (www.simonphotography.com) for over 20 years, with clients including Calvin Klein, Nine West, Tod’s, Mark Fisher, Coach, Diego Della Valle, Tommy Hilfiger, and Guess, among many others.  His work has been published in numerous books and magazines. He is currently working on an art book with Ektoras Binikos, centered on mixology inspired by various artists.                                              


Jutras will design and oversee the construction and creation of the space.  He will also be responsible for the marketing and branding of the company, managing PR, photography, advertisement, and general publicity.

                                                          

Ektoras Binikos and his partner Simon Jutras will offer their guests a magnificent selection of original cocktails for the ultimate sensory experience, together with a distinctive selection of classic top-notch cocktails – gems revisited by Binikos – and an exciting selection of New & Old World wines, a premium assortment of spirits, craft beers and small dishes as distinct and forward-thinking as Binikos' drinks. Besides glorious cocktails, we will offer eclectic live music and amazing performances on selected nights. 

                            



Risks and Challenges

It’s no secret that opening a business in New York City is not for the faint-hearted. It would be easy to get lost in the challenges that such an endeavor might present – or it would if we did not have many years of experience behind us.  Having managed and built other people's businesses over the years, we have acquired the tools to meet any challenges.  Our management skills, enthusiasm, creativity, and passion, combined with our artistic sensibilities, will help us create a unique gathering place where alchemy and art offer a transcendent experience for its guests.



Other Ways You Can Help

If you're unable to make a financial contribution but are still excited about making SUGAR MONK a reality, you can still have a huge impact! Please share this link in your social media pages: 
http://igg.me/at/SugarMonk/x/11018974

Thank you very much for your support. Your contributions and interest in making SUGAR MONK a reality means so much to us!

story:
Thank you for checking out our campaign! We are currently trying to raise funds so we can begin production on our film 'Probable Cause'. We have a passion for the art of film and just want to make this project a reality! Our inspiration for this film stems from the likes of Rob Zombie in the genre of Horror/Comedy. Currently we still have some equipment that needs to be rented as well as some remaining props to be bought. Any contribution or support greatly helps and is highly appreciated!

PLOT SUMMARY:

             In the Town of Brimstone, Connecticut the law is lawless and the police force is run by mad, brutal killers that torture civilians who don’t play by their rules. One night a group of college students pass through the town heading north on a road trip when they are pulled over by the local police. They are two of the town’s most sleazy officers – the ruthless Sergeant Wydell and the manic Officer Thompson. The officers detain the teens for a simple moving violation before taking them against their will to which they find themselves locked in the basement of the precinct. As the taunted college kids endure violent torture at the hands of the corrupt officers and face monstrous entities, they realize that they are in danger of a force much darker and more sinister than any of them could have ever imagined...


WHERE THE FUNDS WILL GO:

All funds raised are going to go towards renting our equipment and purchasing the proper remaining props necessary to make this film happen. They are currently as follows...

(1) Sony FDR AX1 (Camera Rental) - $350.00
(2) Extra Batteries for Camera - $50.00
(1) Filled 301 LED Kit (Lighting Rental) - $260.00
(1) Matthews Car Mounting System Rental - $55.00
(1) Boom Pole Audio Package Rental - $135.00
(1) Sennheiser Lavalier Microphone Rental - $65.00

(1) Mixed Assortment of Body Parts Prop (to make this movie awesome)  - $200.00
(2) Gallons of Fake Blood - $60.00
(1) Custom Made Silicone Mask (for our creature, to make it even more awesome) - $600.00
(2) Custom Molded Silicone Faces (so our actors can have their faces ripped off) - $200.00
(1) Police Car Bar Lights - $125.00
(1) LED Dash Lights - $90.00

(2) Uniforms for Police Officers and Police Belts - $825.00
            (2) Police Shirts - $20/e
           (2) Police Pants - $40/e
           (2) Pairs of Police Boots - $45/e
           (2) Name Tags - $15/e
           (2) Police Belts - $40/e
           (1) Blank Firing Replica .38 - $130.00
           (1) Blank Firing Replica 9mm - $130 .00
           (2) 9mm Extra Magazine - $35/e
           (2) Boxes of Blank Firing Ammunition - $25/e
           (2) Custom Made Police Badges - $50/e
           (2) Pairs of Handcuffs - $15/e

Miscellaneous Costs - $550.00
            Food for Cast and Crew - $350.00
            Gas for transportation - $200.00


Our Cast and Crew:


DIRECTORS:

Patrick Delaney - Writer/Director/Executive Producer
             Patrick is currently in his Junior year at Franklin Pierce University. He was born in Worcester, MA and is a graduate of Saint John's High School in Shrewsbury, where he met fellow director Mark Anthony Aiello during their Sophomore years. Ever since a young age Patrick has had a passion for film, his first experiences stemming from creating several short films in the pre-teen years to gradually working on bigger projects ever since. He has participated in several acting seminars as well as courses on Directing/Producing including Animation and Multi-Camera Production. His inspirations for filmmaking draw from Quentin Tarantino, Martin Scorsese and Rob Zombie, among others.  He plans on declaring a major in Mass Communications with a concentration in Media Production.


Mark Anthony Aiello - Writer/Director
              Mark was born in Worcester, Massachussetts on January 2, 1995. He grew up in the remote town of Sutton, Massachussetts. As a little kid, Aiello always had a fascination with movies. However it wasn’t until his early teens when he first saw the 1995 crime biopic Casino and became heavily influenced by Martin Scorsese. It was also through Scorsese that Aiello was really introduced to the whole world of movies and decided that filmmaking was what he wanted to do for a living. In high school he met Patrick Delaney, another aspiring filmmaker and the two became friends and started collaborating together to make films.


CREW:

Matthew Scoville - Camera Operator/Cinemtographer
              Matthew Scoville is a graduate of Torrington High School in Connecticut, he is currently a Junior at Franklin Pierce University majoring in Film Production. Scoville has taken acting and musical theatre classes at the Beginnings workshop with directors from Wicked, Stomp, and On the Town. He fell in love with film during his Video Production courses in high school. Some of Matthew's influences include Alfred Hitchcock, David Kronenburg, Eli Roth and Steven Spielberg.


Narvicto DeJesus - Art Director
                  Narvicto is going on his Junior year at Lesley University's Art program as an Animation/Illustration Major. There he has taken many courses covering 2D animation and illustration principles and techniques, as well as video editing courses and some minor 3D animation/modeling. He has always had a passion for drawing and being part of creative projects, and draws much influence from comic books, games, and movies for his artwork. Narvicto is also a big fan of action and comedy, as well as abstraction, and draws influence from the subconscious. "Sometimes what you feel is more than you could ever describe. Capturing that is our jobs as artists". Narvicto met the crew of Patrick and Mark in their years together at Saint John's High School. 



CAST:


Eamonn McGrail - Officer Owen Thompson (Lead)



Peter Lewis Walsh - Sergeant Mason Wydell (Lead)


Nate Waddell - Jason (Lead)


Kacie Clinton - Blair (Lead)


Adonis Calderon - Michael (Lead)


Kamisha Lauture - Cadence (Lead)


Chris Faria - Jerry (Supporting)
story_txt:
Thank you for checking out our campaign! We are currently trying to raise funds so we can begin production on our film 'Probable Cause'. We have a passion for the art of film and just want to make this project a reality! Our inspiration for this film stems from the likes of Rob Zombie in the genre of Horror/Comedy. Currently we still have some equipment that needs to be rented as well as some remaining props to be bought. Any contribution or support greatly helps and is highly appreciated!PLOT SUMMARY:             In the Town of Brimstone, Connecticut the law is lawless and the police force is run by mad, brutal killers that torture civilians who don’t play by their rules. One night a group of college students pass through the town heading north on a road trip when they are pulled over by the local police. They are two of the town’s most sleazy officers – the ruthless Sergeant Wydell and the manic Officer Thompson. The officers detain the teens for a simple moving violation before taking them against their will to which they find themselves locked in the basement of the precinct. As the taunted college kids endure violent torture at the hands of the corrupt officers and face monstrous entities, they realize that they are in danger of a force much darker and more sinister than any of them could have ever imagined...WHERE THE FUNDS WILL GO:All funds raised are going to go towards renting our equipment and purchasing the proper remaining props necessary to make this film happen. They are currently as follows...
(1) Sony FDR AX1 (Camera Rental) - $350.00
(2) Extra Batteries for Camera - $50.00
(1) Filled 301 LED Kit (Lighting Rental) - $260.00
(1) Matthews Car Mounting System Rental - $55.00
(1) Boom Pole Audio Package Rental - $135.00
(1) Sennheiser Lavalier Microphone Rental - $65.00
(1) Mixed Assortment of Body Parts Prop (to make this movie awesome)  - $200.00
(2) Gallons of Fake Blood - $60.00
(1) Custom Made Silicone Mask (for our creature, to make it even more awesome) - $600.00
(2) Custom Molded Silicone Faces (so our actors can have their faces ripped off) - $200.00
(1) Police Car Bar Lights - $125.00
(1) LED Dash Lights - $90.00
(2) Uniforms for Police Officers and Police Belts - $825.00            (2) Police Shirts - $20/e
           (2) Police Pants - $40/e           (2) Pairs of Police Boots - $45/e           (2) Name Tags - $15/e           (2) Police Belts - $40/e           (1) Blank Firing Replica .38 - $130.00           (1) Blank Firing Replica 9mm - $130 .00           (2) 9mm Extra Magazine - $35/e           (2) Boxes of Blank Firing Ammunition - $25/e           (2) Custom Made Police Badges - $50/e           (2) Pairs of Handcuffs - $15/e

story:
ÜBERREICH

Im Rahmen der experimentellen Archäologie, in Begleitung einer Professorin und zwei Assistenten, fahren zehn StudentInnen nach Elsarn (heute ein Freilichtmuseum), um zwei Wochen zu Studienzwecken ein Leben wie im 2. Jhdt. n. Chr. nachzuempfinden.

Inhalt:

Ralf und seine Mutter polnischer Abstammung leben zusammen in relativ guten Verhältnissen. Sie kommt aus einer wohlhabenden polnischen Familie und ist nicht verschwenderisch, hat aber ihren Sohn falsch erzogen. Dieser will immer nur das beste Essen haben, kauft mehr als er selbst brauchen kann und wirft die Reste achtlos weg. Er macht zusammen mit seiner Freundin Annette, die auch nur ein Leben in Luxus gewohnt ist, permanent Party macht und nicht arbeiten will, weil ihn die Mutter sowieso erhält. Er schläft oft bis 15 Uhr, badet sich danach sehr lange, zieht sich schön an und geht fein aus. So verbringt er oft die ganze Woche lang. Von seiner Freundin Annette erfährt er von einem Experiment in einem Freilichtmuseum und bekommt von der verantwortlichen Archäologin die Erlaubnis, zusammen mit Annette an dem Experiment teilzunehmen. Als sie im Freilichtmuseum ankommen sind, werden ihnen alle Gegenstände abgenommen die aus der Gegenwart stammen - vor allem die Handys und der Laptop. Sie werden in Kleidung aus dem 2. Jhdt. n. Chr. gesteckt und in einem Wohnhaus aus der damaligen Zeit einquartiert. Dort sind sie erst so richtig mit dem Leben von unseren Vorfahren konfrontiert und die Folgen lassen nicht lange auf sich warten. Mit der Zeit vertiefen sie sich immer mehr in die Vergangenheit und ihr Verhalten ändert sich schlagartig um 180 Grad. Ralf und einige der anderen Studenten weigern sich auf dem Stroh im Schuppen zu schlafen und machen sich auf die Suche nach etwas Essbarem.
Als Ralf erfährt, dass Annette von ihn Kind erwartet, wird sein Leben noch mehr komplizierter, weil er die Frau seiner Träume erst hier begegnet, die ganz andere Einstellung zum Leben hat und aus einer einfachen Familie stammt. Durch wird ihn bewußt, was er bis jetzt in seinem leben falsch gemacht hatte.

Ziel unseres Filmprojektes:

Ein Bewusstsein für sozioökonomische und wirtschaftspolitische Zustände in Europa im Vergleich zu Schwellen- und Entwicklungsländern zu schaffen. In diesem Projekt dargestellt anhand eines Experiments, in dem Studierende der Archäologie in einer Siedlung, die dem 2. Jhdt. n. Chr. angesiedelt ist, für zwei Wochen leben. Sie werden ohne den Vorzügen der modernen Technik und Luxusgütern ihren Alltag bestreiten müssen. Neben den im Drehbuch verankerten Konflikten, werden sicherlich reale Konflikte aufgrund der veränderten Lebensumstände entstehen, die ebenfalls dokumentarisch festgehalten werden (2 Filmprojekte zeitgleich).

Warum man dieses Projekt unterstützen sollte:

Es ist wichtig, ein Bewusstsein für den Reichtum in den industrialisierten Ländern zu schaffen. Und gleichzeitig vor Augen zu führen, unter welchen Umständen andere Menschen, vor allem in den armen Ländern, leben müssen.

Wie wird das gespendete Geld eingesetzt:

Es werden Kostüme aus dem 2. Jhdt. n. Chr. & Gegenwart geschneidert, es müssen Requisiten hergestellt bzw. angekauft werden und es fällt Miete für das Freilichtmuseum Elsarn an (tgl. 150€). Miete für das Gasthaus in Elsarn, Ausstattung und Reinigung der Sanitären Anlagen, Verpflegung für ca. 40 Mitwirkende (3 x tgl.), Equipment (Licht, Kamera, Dolly, Kran,etc.), Miete eines Lieferwagens für den Transport von Equipment und Organisation von Mitfahrgelegenheiten für mitwirkende Personen sowie Transportmöglichkeiten für die Tiere (Schafe, Ziegen, Hunde), nach Abschluss der Dreharbeiten werden zusätzliche Mittel für die Post-Produktion benötigt (Schnitt, Vertonung, Untertitel,...).

Ein Beispiel originalgetreu angefertigter Kleidung.


Unser Team:

Aktuelle Infos & News: ÜBERREICH @ facebook

story:
Short Summary

We are a husband and wife responding to God’s call to use our talents and gifts to build up the Kingdom of God. Our partnership combines 20 years of  retail sales and project management experience and more than 10 years of ministry experience and theological education.

We are establishing a publishing program – The House of Aaron Publishing – to support aspiring anointed authors. We are providing the full services needed to deliver professionally produced books that are theologically sound and easy to read.

We want to spread the message of God’s love and hope to a hurting and weary world through works that inspire, challenge and speak to people of all ages and all walks of life. We are excited to support anointed authors who write inspirational and encouraging works that challenge the reader to grow closer in relationship to God.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $20,690 for the cost of printing, website hosting, editing and graphic design services, publishing software, and subscription fees to produce first run editions of 5 anointed first time authors. We will publish an initial printing of a limited edition compilation Narratives book series written by Veronica Patterson, our premiere anointed author, as well as our next 4 anointed authors. If we don't reach our entire goal, the funds we receive will still be invested in publishing our premiere author. 


We've got some great perks for your tax-deductible donation ranging from a pre-ordered limited edition of the Narratives book to a "Host the Author" party dependent on the level of donation. We have the perfect perk for you, regardless of the size of your contribution. 

The Impact

Your contribution will help provide a platform for authors who have been previously unheard who otherwise may not have an opportunity to be published. Your support will help expand the Kingdom at a time when people need to know about the love of God for themselves.   

Risks & Challenges

We may face challenges with traditional distribution channels with our books. However, we believe our advantage is in the use of electronic media and on-demand printing to reach our customers.

Other Ways You Can Help

Perhaps you just can't contribute. We understand. But you still can help in the following ways:

  • Pray that our campaign is successfully funded.
  • Pray for our premiere anointed author and subsequent anointed authors.
  • Get the word out! Share our campaign with your network.

story:
The Card Wars is a Star Wars fan film/web series that takes you inside an office environment who’s culture and politics are influence by the Star Wars Card Trader mobile app.   You may be asking yourself what is the Star Wars Card Trader app, but like Darth Trader said in the video above you are asking  the wrong question.   

All of us Star Wars fans can't wait until December right, but what will we do with our time and how do you plan for THE EVENT?  I wanted to bring a funny and witty parody of Star Wars: A New Hope if it took place on Earth  in a working office where the Executives (The Empire) were the kids that grew up on Star Wars and of course the fresh out of college employees (Rebel Alliance) would have been kids of those kids so the Star Wars culture would have been ingrained in them and good chances are they were influenced by the names they were given.  Then to introduce a mobile card trading game that has such a fun and dedicated fan base (and great stories I tell you visit the fan feed on any release and be prepared to laugh a lot) and to make the SWCT the main reason why things are done in the company.  All these shenanigans happening that will lead our characters up the premiere of Episode VII: The Force Awakens.

We promise Darth Trader won't spend your donations on building a fully functional Death Star.  Here is a breakdown of our costs of filming season 1 (six episodes in total).


It's important to have a great team to get the work done, and that's what we have.
CREW
The Director of Photography Dale DiMassi is an Emmy and Telly Award-Winning Cinematographer,  production assistants and writers Amanda Aguero, Samantha Cass, and Seth Schneider, a Hollywood composer and myself creator and director Jeremy Lipsey just to name a few.  

CAST
Austin Terrell - Darth Trader
Jaclyn Walsh - Hannah Solo
Hayden Mackey - Duke Skytrader
Kiarra Osakue - Leah
Lisbeth Splawn - Grace Larkin (HR Rep)
Cody Schmitt - Charles Peterson

STILL CASTING.......
Yes we are going to post our casting calls on the backers section, so are you interested in being part of this web series well send us an email and let us know.  We still need roles for Ronald, Bob Kenobi & Gweedo to name a few.  PLUS we need Stormtroopers and other costume cosplay fans to help us out. 

If your a SWCT user we have some exclusive content for you, but if your not we have other stuff you are sure to enjoy.   Who doesn't want a digital card made of them!

This is important as The Card Wars season one will be shot in beautiful Colorado.  Colorado will serve as our Tatooine (no we are not a desert but we have some beautiful sand dunes and amazing sunsets).  There are a couple of key locations that I'm still working on getting like a Colorado landmark to serve as our Cantina, or a local theater to help us out as well.  But most of all as a native I want to show the beauty of Colorado and how diverse our state is in many different ways.   As for next season, well Colorado can serve as a cold planet, or even a forest so you never know what's next.   

There are always risks and challenges when it comes to film, actors schedules, location changes, I mean the odds are against you when making a film.  But never tell me the odds!  We have a professional crew and actors that want to make a fun Star Wars fan web series.  That being said Disney and Lucasfilm own the rights to Star Wars, and Topps for the SWCT app so at any time they can have a say in their content.  However our project falls under the Fair Use of Copyright for parody/satire, and being huge Star Wars fans we want to do a fun fan web series in good taste that fans of all ages can enjoy while you await the opening of Episode VII: The Force Awakens.  All your donations will be spent on the project to launch it and keep in going maybe for season 2...   

Well maybe not our only hope, but it's true without your support, emails, comments, love for our project we have no chance to get this off the ground.  So please share this with your friends, family, and most of all your coworkers in the office!   Feel free to walk around your office wearing a Darth Trader helmet and demanding people to support our project.  Most of the time it's appropriate to use a force choke on someone's wallet if it comes down to it and just remember there is to be "NO DISINTEGRATIONS".

If your a SWCT user we have some exclusive content for you, but if your not we have other stuff you are sure to enjoy.   Who doesn't want a digital card made of them!


This is important as The Card Wars season one will be shot in beautiful Colorado.  Colorado will serve as our Tatooine (no we are not a desert but we have some beautiful sand dunes and amazing sunsets).  There are a couple of key locations that I'm still working on getting like a Colorado landmark to serve as our Cantina, or a local theater to help us out as well.  But most of all as a native I want to show the beauty of Colorado and how diverse our state is in many different ways.   As for next season, well Colorado can serve as a cold planet, or even a forest so you never know what's next.   

    

There are always risks and challenges when it comes to film, actors schedules, location changes, I mean the odds are against you when making a film.  But never tell me the odds!  We have a professional crew and actors that want to make a fun Star Wars fan web series.  That being said Disney and Lucasfilm own the rights to Star Wars, and Topps for the SWCT app so at any time they can have a say in their content.  However our project falls under the Fair Use of Copyright for parody/satire, and being huge Star Wars fans we want to do a fun fan web series in good taste that fans of all ages can enjoy while you await the opening of Episode VII: The Force Awakens.  All your donations will be spent on the project to launch it and keep in going maybe for season 2...   

Well maybe not our only hope, but it's true without your support, emails, comments, love for our project we have no chance to get this off the ground.  So please share this with your friends, family, and most of all your coworkers in the office!   Feel free to walk around your office wearing a Darth Trader helmet and demanding people to support our project.  Most of the time it's appropriate to use a force choke on someone's wallet if it comes down to it and just remember there is to be "NO DISINTEGRATIONS".

story:
Jack Frost and Elsa come to life

Working with Lemons wants to bring the fan-fiction couple of Jack Frost and Elsa (Jelsa) to life in an all new original music video. Introducing the Song, Find a Way. 

Being big fans of magical ice abilities, we felt it was time to unite the powers of Jack and Elsa. This project will introduce you to the moment Jack Frost and Elsa meet for the first time.

Your Involvement

Making these great music videos takes much time and effort. So we are reaching out to all you as a way to make the magic of this story come to life. We love all of our fans and never could have made it this far without you and your love and support. We have some great rewards, but more than that, we have a great community that can be involved at any pledge level.

  • Everyone can be involved - even at just $1.
  • Our goal is to raise $5000 for this video -(it actually costs much more).
  • Dollars raised will go towards special effects and orchestration.
Can't support us with dollars? Getting the word out about this video is just as important! Become one of our social media Lemonade Stands - just Tweet, Facebook, SnapChat, Instgram, Text and even use your phone for what it was meant for and Call - EVERYONE.  We are so grateful for any support you can offer.

If we go over our goal - then what?
  • We can get cool awesome ice powers
  • Full live orchestral music
  • And more...

Launch of Video

We will be premiering this video at CVXLive in Orem, Utah on August 7-8. After the premiere, the video will be available to everyone!

We're super excited about this new video and can't wait to share it with you!


If you have any questions about this campaign, please contact us. This is the first time we've done this and we're sure there are some things we missed - we'll just blame Olaf!

story:
What is a good life? What is happiness? 

For some happiness means a family. For some it means achievement and success. For some, happiness is the freedom to choose how to live life. For some, it is “having it all.”

What if your relationship was at odds with your version of true happiness? Would you say goodbye? How do you say goodbye to someone or even something you deeply love?


All I Want is a truly collaborative ensemble feature film that explores family, friendship, love and letting go.


The Story:

In their ten years of marriage, Mel and Drew have made themselves and their home the center of a tight circle of friends, who are treated like members of their own family.

Tonight, this bond is tested, and things will change forever when Mel and Drew announce the real reason for this celebration.

Ten years of marriage is caught, suddenly, in the glimpse of one evening.


The Team:

Melissa Center is the creator of this madness. She is also playing Mel. Melissa is the creator of web series Missed Connections Live. You can see her on Grimm, Grey's Anatomy, and True Detective. www.melissacenter.com

West Liang is a co-writer/co-director, actor & all around co-conspirator. His award-nominated feature film, Someone I Used to Know was produced by 408 Films (Linsanity) in 2011/12 and and is now available on Amazon. www.westliang.com

Ruben O'Malley is a D.P. who's credits include Jeff Lipsky's Twelve Thirty, award winning documentary Showfolk, and the recent Marc Meyer’s film How He Fell in Love with Matt McGorry and Amy Hargreaves as star crossed lovers. 


Ensemble of Actors who've inspired this story

You can see these fabulous people in Masters of Sex, Power, American Sniper, Love Thy Neighbor, Grey's Anatomy, NCIS & More!

   

Why this project?

This project is important to us on many levels:
  • We are passionate about honest, authentic storytelling in a landscape where violence, explosions, & gratuitous sex rule (Not that we don't love those things. We just want to see stories that connect to people on a deeper level too)
  • No on is alone. It's easy to feel lost, confused & uncertain when faced with major life changes. We want to start a conversation about hard life things that we all deal with on a daily basis.
  • LA is cooler than you think. We want to draw attention to the LA you don't typically hear or read about. We are collaborating with some local small business by weaving them into our story. Already, Bon Vivant, an Atwater Village market/cafe has said "YES" to partnering with us!
  • Diversity matters. We want to represent a cross-section of REAL PEOPLE that happen to be black, white, male, female, hispanic, asian, gay, & straight in a way that is truthful. 
  • Fuck Hollywood. Statistics show those holding executive positions at TV studios are 96 percent white and 71 percent male, and the executives at film studios are 94 percent white and 100 percent male. This is an opportunity for us to take matters into our own hands and change the conversation about what can/can't get made.


What We Need & What You Get

In order for us to shoot this film, we need to raise AT LEAST $20,000, but guess what?!

We've partnered with From the Heart Productions, a non-profit organization. As such, ALL DONATIONS are TAX-DEDUCTIBLE!

Here's where the donations will go:

  1. Crew - Filmmaking takes a village! We need to support the people that will be supporting us in bringing our story to YOU.
  2. Equipment - In order for this film to look, feel and sound the best, we need some serious equipment!
  3. Props - We can't throw a party without stuff.
  4. Costumes/Hair/Makeup - You want us to look good, right?
  5. Insurance - If shit breaks, we pay.
  6. Food - We need to feed people. A LOT of people!
  7. Editor - We need to piece this story together so you can see it!
SURPASSING OUR GOAL:
If we can surpass our goal, we can....

  1. Pay our actors what we/they deserve.
  2. Get a head start on post-production costs.
  3. Have $$ to submit to festivals.
  4. Have $$ for marketing costs.
  5. Have $$ to deliver this product to YOU!


Risks & Challenges

We realize that we will encounter obstacles as we piece this ambitious tale together. We cannot succeed without your help and support and thank you for taking a leap and believing in our vision!


What Can You Do?

First, Donate. Obviously.

But...the more people that know about ALL I WANT, the more chance we have to meet (or surpass!) our goal. So, while, we'd love if you can pledge some money, we'd also love you to spread the word by:

  • Email - email our link to 5 people you think will connect with our story
  • Twitter  - follow our feed @ALLIWantFilm & tweet our link, with the hashtag #ALLIWant.
  • Facebook - post our indiegogo link to your page and like our page!

Facebook - post our indiegogo link to your page and like our page!

story:
Who we are:


The Rangjung Prison Dharma Project is the only program that brings engaged meditation practice to both the inmate population and correction officers at Rikers Island Correctional Facility. 

We operate as part of New York Tsurphu Goshir Dharma Center, a 501(c)3 non-profit Buddhist temple in Brooklyn, New York, which is organized around the basic principle of trying to allow others a way to settle into their own experience of wholeness, peace and connection to the world through meditation. 

We began this work in April 2014 initially offering meditation instruction, meditation sessions and discussion groups to the female inmate population at Rikers.  Not long afterwards we were approached by the warden of a maximum security facility to offer weekly meditation for the Correction Officers as a way to help them cope with the difficult and unpredictable nature of their work as well as learn how to develop mindfulness when difficult emotions arise so that clear decisions are more easily made. 

Based upon the success of our work with the Correction Officers and the new changes that the Department of Correction has been instituting, we also now work with the incarcerated adolescent population, the male population in a maximum security facility, as well as one of the new Enhanced Security Housing units which serves as an alternative to solitary confinement for inmates involved in violent attacks while incarcerated.  This funding will allow us to expand our services to a new facility for young adults as well as a new transgender program.

Our work is aimed at allowing all we serve, inmates and officers, to experience a break from the difficulties they face at Rikers through meditation as it relates to stress reduction, settling into one's own sense of dignity, and exploring what underlying thoughts and feelings are alive for them in that moment.

We are all volunteers and are not compensated at all for this work, and given the strength of the partnership we have with the Department of Correction we are trying to raise funds to help us expand in a healthy way that allows us to continue providing compassionate care to people who find themselves in very difficult, challenging situations.

Your donation will not only help keep our program running, it will help us with the important work of training new volunteers and allow us to meet the growing demand of our services at Rikers.



Some of our volunteers:



Justin von Bujdoss (Repa Dorje Odzer) is the resident-lama of New York Tsurphu Goshir Dharma Center where he serves as primary teacher, co-Founder and Executive Director.  He is also founder and director of the Rangjung Prison Dharma Project.  Justin been practicing Buddhism since 1995 and has studied with and received practice instructions from many great meditation teachers from the traditions of Theravada, Mahayana, and Vajrayana Buddhism.  He is also currently a staff chaplain with Calvary Hospice, through which he helps to bring contemplative and spiritual support to those at the end-of-life.  Justin is committed to bringing the insights born from meditation practice into the experience of an integrated life.


Darren Ornitz has been meditating for 4 years.  His meditation practice continues to bring him benefit in relating more healthily to his emotions, especially surrounding anxiety and depression.  He has been enthusiastic to share these benefits with and get to know the community at Rikers, especially the adolescent population which he has spent a considerable amount of time with.  During the day Darren works as a photojournalist/documentary photographer as well as a boat captain during the summer.  Darren lives in Brooklyn and spends a lot of time on different assignments around the globe. 


John Bravo DeMicoli facilitates meditation groups with the female inmates at Rose M. Singer Center. He enjoys sharing what he's learning about meditation and providing "a chill, supportive space where inmates can relax, talk, laugh, not be judged or ordered around, process life and just be people." John has a background in developmental psychology and education policy, and is looking forward to expanding our offerings to the Rikers community, including contemplative art & writing, and exploring meditation as a means of preventing and healing from violence against women.


Jae Carey is the newest member of the Rangjung Prison Dharma Project. She has been instructing meditation for the past six years at Brooklyn Zen Center, where she practices with her teacher, Teah Strozer. The heart of the matter for Jae is finding ways to share meditative presence with those who are in particularly stressful or fearful situations. Currently a student at the New York Zen Center for Contemplative Care, Jae intends to continue offering meditation instruction at Rikers, as well as exploring hospice and doula work.


Synnove Trier has been practicing meditation for over 12 years with Rock Blossom Sangha in Brooklyn, a Buddhist group in the tradition of Thich Nath Hanh.  She has a Ph.D in Clinical Psychology and worked for many years at a public mental health center in Brentwood, Long Island, in a large Latino community. She is recently retired.  Synnove grew up in Germany but has been living in Brooklyn for a long time. She is married and has two grown children.


Kate Lennon has been meditating for over 5 years. Her practice has brought many benefits, especially around chronic pain from an autoimmune disease, depression, and anxiety and she is grateful for the opportunity to share this experience with others. She is a client relationship manager at an international law firm by day, and watercolorist and crafter by night. Kate lives in Brooklyn with her beloved terrier and boyfriend.

 

What We Need & What You Get


We are seeking your support to help us continue our work and increase the impact of our successful program.

Raising $30,000 will to help us in the following ways:

  1. Create a one-day a week paid position for two of our volunteers so that they can manage and coordinate our growing number of volunteers and maintain relationships with Department of Correction staff on Riker's Island.
  2. Develop and print educational materials to further support inmates and officers.
  3. Develop a support program for inmates after they are released from jail to continue meditation practice as well as the therapeutic relationships formed with our volunteers.
  4. Increase our offerings to other jail populations at Rikers.
  5. Recruit, train and support new volunteers.

Our perks and benefits are listed on the right side; the t-shirts feature the logo of the dharma center designed by renowned female graffiti artist Queen Andrea (pictured at the bottom of this page). The limited edition photograph choices are from a recent trip to our parent monastery in Sikkim, India, taken by Lucian Read. You can see those photographs here:




How our work makes a difference:


The impact of our work at Rikers has been felt by many, from inmates to correction officers and to the commissioner of the Department of Correction.  Here are a few testimonies:

"The Rangjung Prison Dharma Project has a working-relationship with the Department since April, 2014. The Rangjung Prison Dharma Project provides meditation classes and emotional support to the incarcerated population and uniform staff and is the only one of this kind on Rikers Island. The team helps the incarcerated population explore and gain insight about the effects of negative thoughts and feelings and their response to them, some of which might have contributed to their incarceration. In addition to services provided to the incarcerated population, the team work with Correction Officers to manage stress, anxiety and exhaustion.   We look forward to continuing this highly productive relationship with the Rangjung Prison Dharma Project and encourage their efforts on Rikers Island."

-Department of Correction

To date we have served over 2,000 inmates and over 200 correction officers, and we have been asked to increase our services to reach a larger swath of the 8,000 to 10,000 inmates who are detained at Rikers at any given point in time.

"Coming to meditation is the only way that I can deal with the anxiety that I feel as I wait for sentencing."

Inmate

It is not uncommon for inmates to be detained at Rikers for as long as five years while waiting for sentencing.  During this long period of time inmates struggle with a wide range of difficult emotions, ranging from sadness to anxiety, depression, anger, rage, and loneliness.  We provide vital support to help inmates cope with being incarcerated and the effects that incarceration have on all of the spheres of their lives and relationships.

"Since I've been here, I've been separated from my family and my baby boy.  I am reminded every day about what I did that put me here and took me away from what I should be doing: taking care of my son. Meditation helps me see how I'm feeling and see some of the ways I made mistakes through my reactions."

Inmate

Part of your donation will help us to develop a support program that will continue the benefit of the deep connections that we make with inmates while they are incarcerated. These benefits of being heard, supported, witnessed, and enriched through the contemplative support of meditation practice can continue as inmates make the adjustment to re-entry after release from incarceration.


"This is a very stressful place.  No one wants to be here.  But we are.  Meditation makes me feel peaceful.  I feel that even here, in jail, I can really feel who I am."

Inmate

Part of the stress of being incarcerated often includes feeling written-off by friends, family, and society at large.  A large part of what we do in addition to offering meditation is offering supportive conversation and dialogue as a way of exploring what makes those we serve feel whole, empowered and cared-for.


"Before I began meditating I felt closed to the world around me and my fellow officers.  Now I understand how the stress of this job and the constant exposure to violence had been affecting me both while on tour and at home.  Now I feel more in control of how I react to my surroundings."

Correction Officer

There are an estimated 8,000 Correction Officers who work at Rikers performing tours between the 10 jail buildings on the island, transporting inmates to various court buildings for trial as well as to other locations.  Their jobs are stressful, unpredictable and often involve the threat of having to deal with violence on a daily basis, or being assaulted while on the job.  We currently provide meditation and emotional/contemplative support at one maximum security facility on the island.  Your donation will allow us to be able to provide needed support to the brave women and men who work under circumstances that most of us could not.



Other Ways You Can Help


We recognize that some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help.  Help us by spreading the word about our campaign, use the share tools, use facebook, twitter, or regular email. 

We know that we can meet this funding goal. The work we do is important. Let's work together as a community to bring the benefits of meditation to everyone at Rikers!

Lastly, if you would like to volunteer with us, or know someone who might, contact us for more information at:  info@goshir.org

We thank you for your wonderful support!

 relationship with the Rangjung Prison Dharma Project and encourage 
their efforts
on Rikers Island." -Department of CorrectionTo date we have served over 2,000 inmates and over 200 correction officers, and we have been asked to increase our services to reach a larger swath of the 8,000 to 10,000 inmates who are detained at Rikers at any given point in time."Coming to meditation is the only way that I can deal with the anxiety that I feel as I wait for sentencing."InmateIt is not uncommon for inmates to be detained at Rikers for as long as five years while waiting for sentencing.  During this long period of time inmates struggle with a wide range of difficult emotions, ranging from sadness to anxiety, depression, anger, rage, and loneliness.  We provide vital support to help inmates cope with being incarcerated and the effects that incarceration have on all of the spheres of their lives and relationships.
"Since I've been here, I've been separated from my family and my baby 
boy.  I am reminded every day about what I did that put me here and took
 me away from what I should be doing: taking care of my son. Meditation 
helps me see how I'm feeling and see some of the ways I made mistakes 
through my reactions."

Inmate
Part of your donation will help us to develop a support program that will continue the benefit of the deep connections that we make with inmates while they are incarcerated. These benefits of being heard, supported, witnessed, and enriched through the contemplative support of meditation practice can continue as inmates make the adjustment to re-entry after release from incarceration.

"This is a very stressful place.  No one wants to be here.  But we are. 
 Meditation makes me feel peaceful.  I feel that even here, in jail, I 
can really feel who I am." 

Inmate
Part of the stress of being incarcerated often includes feeling written-off by friends, family, and society at large.  A large part of what we do in addition to offering meditation is offering supportive conversation and dialogue as a way of exploring what makes those we serve feel whole, empowered and cared-for.

"Before I began meditating I felt closed to the world around me and my fellow officers.  Now I understand how the stress of this job and the constant exposure to violence had been affecting me both while on tour and at home.  Now I feel more in control of how I react to my surroundings."
Correction Officer
There are an estimated 8,000 Correction Officers who work at Rikers performing tours between the 10 jail buildings on the island, transporting inmates to various court buildings for trial as well as to other locations.  Their jobs are stressful, unpredictable and often involve the threat of having to deal with violence on a daily basis, or being assaulted while on the job.  We currently provide meditation and emotional/contemplative support at one maximum security facility on the island.  Your donation will allow us to be able to provide needed support to the brave women and men who work under circumstances that most of us could not.

Other Ways You Can Help 
We recognize that some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help.  Help us by spreading the word about our campaign, use the share tools, use facebook, twitter, or regular email.  
We know that we can meet this funding goal. The work we do is important. Let's work together as a community to bring the benefits of meditation to everyone at Rikers!
Lastly, if you would like to volunteer with us, or know someone who might, contact us for more information at:  info@goshir.orgWe thank you for your wonderful support!

story:
What We're About

Hey! Bethany here, I'm the writer, cinematographer, and co-producer for The Girls of Summer. I'm going into my final semester of film school at Arizona State University this fall and this  film is my last hurrah. My experience comes mainly from the gaffing and camera departments, having worked on some 30+ films in the last year and a half working as gaffer, key grip, cinematographer/director of photography, and assistant camera.

This campaign is extremely important to me, not only because graduating depends upon it getting completed, but because it's about a subject that is near and dear to me: fastpitch softball. There are little to no films about softball, let alone fastpitch, and the few that there are make a mockery of the sport. So this short film is about breaking those walls down and showing that "like a girl" isn't as demeaning as it's become.

By contributing to this project you're not only helping me and my collaborators but you are helping the sport of fastpitch softball. By working together we can achieve more than working alone and elevate the young women and girls that play this sport to a spotlight that seems to be diminished in the light of men's sports and poor stereotypes. Oh, and did I mention the perks?


What We Need & What You Get

Our budget is pretty massive for such a small film, but most of the costs come from the costuming department. For anyone who has ever had to order uniforms for a sport, you know it's not cheap. We are going for authentic, to make the film look as close to real as possible. So here's our breakdown:

  • Costumes: $5,513.88

         - Jerseys and Pants for 9 softball players: $549.90 + $449.90 = $999.80

         - Jerseys and Pants for 9 baseball players: $549.90 + $349.90 = $899.80

         - Socks: $164.80

         - Belts: $119.80

         - Hats: $69.90

         - Helmets: $271.88

         - Bats: $739.96

         - Gloves: $583.64

         - Cleats: $799.80

         - Batting Gloves: $127.92

         - Gear Bags: $469.79

         - Catcher's Gear: $194.97

         - Speedos: $71.82

  • Location Fees: $1,380
  • Food: $1,500
  • Additional Camera Equipment (not rented from ASU): $900
  • Insurance : $100
  • Additional Wiggle Room Costs: $606.12
TOTAL: $10,000
We're doing the flexible funding so the campaign will continue past our allotted 60 days if we do not reach our goal, but hopefully that will not be the case.

The Impact

As a backer, you may be asking yourself "why should I give my money to this film?" And that is a very good question. Here's probably the best answer:

Donating to this project has several overall accomplishments. 

         First, by lending us a few dollars that puts us one step closer to actually making The Girls of Summer. 

         Second, the story is an uplifting and inspiring story for not only the young girls and women that play softball, but for women in general. It's a story that we are proud  to say encourages women to think, act, and play "like a girl." 

        Third is that this is a great opportunity to help bring fastpitch softball to the big screen, which has never happened in a way in which to showcase the sport. 

         Fourth is to help a few college seniors on their last endeavor in order to get their diplomas.

So honestly can you think of a better way to help inspire, encourage, and lift up young girls that are pushed down by society than through a film that deals with a topic close to their hearts?

Risks & Challenges

Making a film is hard work; it takes time, patience, dedication, and money. As college filmmakers we have have all except the latter. We are willing to risk our time to turn out a great project and we ask you to risk your money to help make our combined dream come true.

Other Ways You Can Help

After you have contributed, or if you can't there are still ways you can help. Follow us on Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/TheGirlsOfSummerMovie), Twitter (https://twitter.com/GrlsoSummer), and Instagram (https://instagram.com/girls_of_summer_movie/). From there share us with your friends to help spread the word about this project. Use our hashtag (#thegirlsofsummer) to get us trending. Plus by following any of our pages you'll stay up to date on the progress of the film, from pre-production notes and thanks, to production photos, and post-production updates.

story:
We hope everyone who visits this page will consider contributing by selecting a perk to the right. Be a part of an independent movie that tells an original story and gives creative opportunities to fresh talent!

What is TINY DANCERS?

TINY DANCERS is a feature-length comedy about a young exotic dancer who is arrested and has to perform community service by teaching young girls how to dance. 

It's like BAD SANTA meets DANCE MOMS.

Why are we doing this?

We believe that storytelling is one of the most powerful communication tools in the world. Storytelling through film remains one the most potent ways to communicate an idea or feeling to a worldwide audience.

TINY DANCERS is a great opportunity to become a strong creative showcase for women. For decades, women in mainstream film have been marginalized in thankless supporting roles. Women under 25 are frequently objectified in a male-dominated entertainment industry while roles for women over 25 continue to shrink.

At BIRDS EYE, we've been creating female-centric projects for the past several years. From comedies like BEST BUDS to horror films like THE BEACH HOUSE, nearly all of our screenplays start with a multi-faceted female protagonist.

The character of Melody Daniels (played by Brittany Cascone) is a single, hard-working woman who refuses to be defined by the man that she's with. We believe audiences could use more strong female characters like Melody.


What is BIRDS EYE FILM?

Birds Eye Film, LLC is a film development and production company founded by Patrick & Ashley Russell in 2011. Having produced numerous, award-winning short films and ad campaigns, the company's goal has always been to create original stories for a wide, adult audience.
As our first feature-length film, TINY DANCERS represents a big leap forward for us. We understand the risks involved and how quickly production costs can escalate. That's why we're reaching out to friends, family and everyone else who considers themselves a fan of independent filmmaking. 
We simply want to make a GREAT and HILARIOUS movie that people can enjoy for years to come.


Where does the money go?

We're fortunate to own much of our camera and grip equipment in-house. That means that the $25K we are seeking to raise will specifically go to:
     ● Hiring SAG actors
     ● Paying for locations
     ● Hiring crew (sound, PAs, etc)
     ● Additional equipment (lights, dolly, etc.)
By pledging just $1, you'll receive an exclusive photo signed by the main cast. For $100, you'll be given a limited-edition T-shirt, a printed shooting script, a digital download of the final film, plus more.
The bottom line is that anyone who pledges to this campaign will receive something tangible in return, besides our enormous gratitude :)



What happens if I pledge money and the campaign doesn't reach its goal?

We're still making the film! That's right, we're putting our own money into this project so we can turn our dream into a reality. Don't believe us? Just check out our page of short films, all of which were funded exclusively through BIRDS EYE:

http://birdseyefilm.com/videos/

Doing this alone isn't nearly as much fun as getting other people's involvement. That's why we need your help!


What happens if I want to get involved but can't pledge any money?

That's OK! Just forward this page to people you know, telling them what an exciting project you think this is. Use the SHARE buttons at the top of the page to help spread the word.


This film has the potential to employ over a hundred people in the South Florida area, both behind-the-scenes and in front of the camera. We take that responsibility seriously, and can't wait to put on an amazing show for everyone!

story:
Most women in the unemployed arena struggle daily with
finances. They have a heart and desire to work. Many are called to interviews,
follow up interviews, some are even hired on the spot at job fairs. Their lack
of money creates transportation problems, as well as no means to get
appropriate clothing, or hairstyle. The
reality of the matter is that if you don’t have income or a support system, how
will you be able to obtain all you need to have a successful interview? We
believe first impressions last a lifetime, so let me Su-Dress you.



My name is Kimberly Watson Irions and I would like to draw
your attention to this great cause for women. As a licensed professional
stylist for over 15 years, I truly understand how important a woman look,
builds on her confidence. I currently
hold a degree in Theology from the River Bible institute, which helps me to
play a vital role in the caring, and nurturing of women. Su-Dress you is an up and rising community
based project. We open doors for women needing clothes, shoes, accessories, bus
passes, cab fees, or gas cards to get to interviews. I also apply my God given
talent by providing free salon services. That’s right free! We also offer
interview tips, basic interview etiquette, and suggestions to enhance their
professional skillsets.



Su-dress strictly operates from heartfelt donations from
people like you. By meeting our funding goal, it will be possible to bring our
vision to fruition and help many women along the way. I plan to dress 1000 women in the Tampa, and
surrounding areas. Please help me to fulfill my goal of $23,000. Let’s not let
one ride, one dress, one style stop someone from being successful.



Please contribute to this unique cause so that I may bless
1000 women.



Come on and Su-dress someone, dressing them for success.

story:
Who We Are:

'Catch' made its West Coast premiere in San Diego, CA at the International Bullying Prevention Association's Annual Conference is 2014.

The short play was written with the intention of putting students, faculty, administration, and parents on an even playing field, encouraging honest conversation, emotions, connections, and debate. In order to better our school, home, and individual communities, we must forget what we think we know and listen to each person's words and stories. There is such a problem in our society both in school, online, and in the work place with bullying, harassment, negativity, and harmful physical/emotional behavior. This play asks the difficult questions that we sometimes skim over, demands answers, and digs deep into “finding how to fix what’s in people’s hearts.” Raw and honest, this was written for those who have not found their voice and are desperate for someone to hear their story.

Our goal is to turn our traveling show into a half hour film, where it will be incorporated into a full bullying prevention curriculum that will be sold to high schools both nationally and internationally.

Call to Action:

As most creative projects, "Catch" was created to make a fundamental change for our schools, and the team involved has worked tirelessly for over a year and a half for no pay. That's a year and a half of writing, editing, long meetings, long readings, long phone calls, networking, long hours in the car traveling, and late nights, all between everyone's busy schedules, day jobs, and personal life. Looking back, those efforts have been some of the most rewarding.  Because we believe that the impact of this message is so crucial to our current & future students, school faculty & administration, and parents, we have come to the point where funding is necessary to pay other professionals to help us properly create the film.  It isn't just necessary. It's mandatory.  In order to get it to students & schools across the country, we have to do the best job we possibly can, and cannot sacrifice telling the story or building the prevention curriculum. This is for a group that needs a voice. And that voice has no limits. It is too big for a price tag.

The team is compromised of professionals within the film & theatre industry, the fields of social work & psychology, and bullying prevention activists.  This team not only wants to provide the media aspect of this project, but we want to offer live performances with in depth talk backs to schools that request us.  The funds we raise are far past appreciated--this campaign has the potential to make "Catch" a strong, new face of bullying prevention.

It takes a village to raise a child, right? We believe in it. We stand by it. You may never meet all the students impacted, but you will see the ripple effect throughout your community. We are that movement for the future. And we need your help.

What We Need: The Breakdown

Below is a breakdown of what the funding will cover

  • Cinematographer/Director: Equipment, production meetings, filming, editing.
  • Sound Mixer: Equipment, production meetings, recording, mixing, editing.
  • PA: Organization, production meetings, "go to" person in charge of schedule, actors, & everything off camera.
  • Actors (3): Professional actors for a week of filming.
  • Assistant Director/Acting Coach: Production meetings, rehearsal, pre-production coaching.
  • Housing, travel, food for cast & crew.
  •  Location costs
  • Props, set, and costuming.
  • Post Production Materials for Purchase of Final Product
  • Marketing & Advertising

The Impact

What makes us different? Why contribute to this specific bullying prevention project?

[Words from the Playwright]:

"The challenge in this piece, as a writer, was to develop a script that speaks for the students and does not preach to them. There is plenty of research and prevention methods which are fantastic, but the worst thing we can do is shove it down the throats of students who are already desensitized to the conversation. I wanted to create a piece that changes what we think we already know, as well as the direction we are going to better our schools, students, faculty, and social media realms. There will be moments in this play that may be shocking, frustrating, and outrageous. I hope that through (student) Carter and (principal) Tuckman's raw conversation, we as an audience can entertain new thoughts without necessarily accepting them as truth. Who is the bully? Who is the victim? What meaning do these labels bring? As a society, we are demanded by our youth to look at the individual stores and circumstances, listen to their words, and empower them as further adults. As students, we empower the adults and fellow students around us./ We must listen to each others' words. We must examine each story to find the truth at the root of it all. And we will. If we choose to look."     

Inspired by Holden from J.D. Salinger's 'The Catcher in the Rye" and real students, this play/film does not hesitate to talk about those things that are the hardest, yet the most necessary.

Plot:

[A student. A principal. A gun. 40 minutes of honest conversation.]

It’s the evening before Christmas break, and Principle Tuckman is sitting in his office finishing his last bit of work. He is surrounded by moving boxes, and he is exhausted. A female student enters his office, demanding to talk. Tuckman tries to get her to make an appointment, but she is refusing to leave, explaining she has something very important to discuss with him. After polite arguing for a few moments, the student pulls a gun out of her backpack and holds it in her hands. The ball is in Tuckman’s court. Or is it?

Through the next hour, we learn about a boy named Allie Field who is severely bullied and the reason for Carter’s visit. Through sharp banter and honest conversation, the two harshly debate bullying, harassment, school policies, teachers, students, and ask the tough questions that have no definite answers. Within the conversation of Allie, we learn what is at the root of Carter’s visit, and Principal Tuckman is faced with a very difficult decision.

This is one conversation you can’t run from, and isn’t watered down. It is meant to spark debate, push conversation between student and teacher, and paints a not-so-pretty picture of the real struggles of life as a student. It’s gritty, heartfelt, and begs the question of how to “fix what’s in people’s hearts”.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute money, but want to take part? Here's how:

Follow us on Facebook & Twitter, visit our website, and share our posts with friends, family, students, teachers, and parents.

Help us get our name out there. There are so many teenagers and adults who need to hear Carter's story. With your help, we can reach so many more.

We are that movement for the future. And we need your help. 
  What We Need: The Breakdown
 Below is a breakdown of what the funding will cover  Cinematographer/Director: Equipment, production meetings, filming, editing.
 Sound Mixer: Equipment, production meetings, recording, mixing, editing.
 PA: Organization, production meetings, "go to" person in charge of schedule, actors, & everything off camera.
Actors (3): Professional actors for a week of filming.
Assistant Director/Acting Coach: Production meetings, rehearsal, pre-production coaching.
Housing, travel, food for cast & crew.
 Location costs
Props, set, and costuming.
Post Production Materials for Purchase of Final Product
Marketing & Advertising
    The Impact What makes us different? Why contribute to this specific bullying prevention project?
[Words from the Playwright]:
"The challenge in this piece, as a writer, was to develop a script that speaks for the students and does not preach to them. There is plenty of research and prevention methods which are fantastic, but the worst thing we can do is shove it down the throats of students who are already desensitized to the conversation. I wanted to create a piece that changes what we think we already know, as well as the direction we are going to better our schools, students, faculty, and social media realms. There will be moments in this play that may be shocking, frustrating, and outrageous. I hope that through (student) Carter and (principal) Tuckman's raw conversation, we as an audience can entertain new thoughts without necessarily accepting them as truth. Who is the bully? Who is the victim? What meaning do these labels bring? As a society, we are demanded by our youth to look at the individual stores and circumstances, listen to their words, and empower them as further adults. As students, we empower the adults and fellow students around us./ We must listen to each others' words. We must examine each story to find the truth at the root of it all. And we will. If we choose to look."      
Inspired by Holden from J.D. Salinger's 'The Catcher in the Rye" and real students, this play/film does not hesitate to talk about those things that are the hardest, yet the most necessary. 
  Plot:
[A student. A principal. A gun. 40 minutes of honest conversation.]
It’s the evening before Christmas break, and Principle Tuckman is sitting in his office finishing his last bit of work. He is surrounded by moving boxes, and he is exhausted. A female student enters his office, demanding to talk. Tuckman tries to get her to make an appointment, but she is refusing to leave, explaining she has something very important to discuss with him. After polite arguing for a few moments, the student pulls a gun out of her backpack and holds it in her hands. The ball is in Tuckman’s court. Or is it?
Through the next hour, we learn about a boy named Allie Field who is severely bullied and the reason for Carter’s visit. Through sharp banter and honest conversation, the two harshly debate bullying, harassment, school policies, teachers, students, and ask the tough questions that have no definite answers. Within the conversation of Allie, we learn what is at the root of Carter’s visit, and Principal Tuckman is faced with a very difficult decision.
This is one conversation you can’t run from, and isn’t watered down. It is meant to spark debate, push conversation between student and teacher, and paints a not-so-pretty picture of the real struggles of life as a student. It’s gritty, heartfelt, and begs the question of how to “fix what’s in people’s hearts”.
  Other Ways You Can Help Can't contribute money, but want to take part? Here's how:
Follow us on Facebook & Twitter, visit our website, and share our posts with friends, family, students, teachers, and parents.  Help us get our name out there. There are so many teenagers and adults who need to hear Carter's story. With your help, we can reach so many more.

story:
Over this last year and a half I have lead up an initiative to empower and encourage individuals to “KeepShooting” for their dreams & goals.  I have hosted seminars and workshops over the past year to bring enlightenment youth and adults. Well, the message has impacted someone (Praise God!) and I have been asked to help a group of women who have a story that usually is kept quiet… a story about overcoming Domestic Violence.

A Documentary & Awareness Seminar has birthed through meeting these ladies. This documentary is called “UNBEATABLE…” it will be screened on October 24, 2015 in Columbia, SC.  We are going to help bring awareness to domestic violence so victims, relatives and friends know they are not alone; also how and where they all can get assistance to be over comers too.

On quote from a survivor "I knew I had had enough and it was time to get out when I heard the gun click..." This is not uncommon in the state of South Carolina. South Carolina ranks second in the nation for women killed by men according to the Violence Policy Center. Of the homicide victims who knew their offenders, 68% (26 victims) were murdered by a husband, common-law husband, ex-husband, or boyfriend.

I am asking for your assistance to help us increase awareness and make this project a reality.  Over the last 3 months we have begun working with the resources we have, however we still need funds  to cover video & editing equipment, regional travel to incident locations for interviews, and secure the location for the Screening & Awareness Seminar during Domestic Violence Month (October 24th).

I ask you pray and mediate on this amazing cause to help save someone life; by bringing awareness domestic violence, which is the way of life for so many, especially here in South Carolina.  If you will like to make a donation you can follow this link http://igg.me/at/UnbeatableColumbia/x/10518993.  I appreciate the consideration and the support. Please spread the word, to anyone who may benefit.

story:
Poster by Bernabe Camacho

Short Summary

Hello guys! My name is Steve! Those who know me know how much I love not only the world of horror but also the character of Jason Voorhees. Over the years many people have attempted to make low budget films in the attempts of recreating that 80's feel. I am about to make that happen. based off my "slasher" persona, my team and I are looking to produce a film that not only enhances what a horror film is, but also celebrate its historic impact in motion cinema. We will be using old school prosthetics just like the old days. We have several locations and spots that are perfect for filming and some of our talent have appeared in numerous shows, movies, photoshoots and more!
We have already shot 15 minutes of the movie.  All we need to film is 65 more minutes and the film will be finished. 

NEW ITEM... FILM SLATE (Signed or not signed, your choice) 


Here are the main Cast/Crew:

Jonathan A. Moody (Writer-Producer-Director) as Kyle 

Brittany Nichole as Shannen

Stephen "The Slasher" Sturges (Producer) as Deputy Josh Cooper 


Andre Bland as Danny 

Tiffany Armstrong (Producer) as Chelsea 

Kara Brown as Autumn 

Eliza Jayne (Producer) as Zoe 

Troy Hepner as Brian Halloway 


Andrea Marie as Gabrielle 


And John Johnson (Director of Photography/Editor) as Sheriff Kelton 


What We Need & What You Get

What are we asking for and what do we need? our goal for this film is $5,000. Why that much? Believe it or not, the majority of this will go to securing permits and equipment. Our entire staff are volunteering their time to participate and perform in this film. We are basically fans making a movie for the fans. Our perks allow you to not only get your name in our product, but also may get you a role! Ever wanted to die in a bloody gruesome way? It could happen here! We have experiences directors and cameramen ready to bring the world of horror to life. Any contributions would be greatly appreciated. Aside from permits and equipment, funds will also go for basic crew supplies such as small snacks and bottled waters. Help us in bring the 'slasher" persona to film!

The Impact

Movies today rely on huge budgets to give us "eye candy". Some of motion picture cinema's biggest and most successful films haven't used one ounce of CGI. Our film is a throwback to the days when molds and kits were used instead of cgi. Its been argued that practical effects are even better and look more realistic than there cgi counterparts. Aside from having 2 professional sfx artists on board, we will be using the best equipment we can get. Once our film comes to live, we hope it expands beyond youtube. We want the world to see not only can a good horror movie be made for next to nothing, but that the genre itself still offers something new.

Risks & Challenges

The obvious risk is coming off as another low budget schlop of a film. That is far from my intention. I value my time where if i put my own time and money into something i want it to be the best. Every dollar we raise will help us. As someone who loves horror, i've seen my share of horrible movies,,what went wrong and why they didnt work. I want to not only make a movie that looks good but is done professionally and in the best way possible.

Other Ways You Can Help

Stay tuned for updates regarding our facebook page! Even if you can't donate you can help spread the word around. Any publicity is good publicity :)
