Main character, Darla Aimes, is convinced she is suffering from an incurable illness. Darla experiences vivid dreams that are eerily familiar.  She religiously consoles with her doctor, Dr. Stine, with hopes that he can cure her of these dreams with the different dosages of prescribed drugs.

Is Darla really sick? Is Dr. Stine truly trying to help her or use the unique case as an experiment? Will she ever get better?
In order to find out the answer to any of these questions we need your help to have the resources to allow this story to unfold.

Who We Are
Gabrielle Lunger- Writer/Editor 

Daniel Cimini- DirectorWe are two filmmakers that have worked together on projects ranging from short narratives to music videos. Daniel takes care of the directing progress and casting. Gabby takes care of the post production. Together, we create films that cause the viewers to question what they've seen and how they feel. Our content may be controversial but it addresses issues that the general public may be afraid still exists. We create characters who are faced with real and unimaginable choices with the uncertainty if they will make it out alive. The Process We are currently still in pre-production. We have casted the roles with promising actors and are beginning to lock down our locations. In order to continue we need the funding that will allows us to pull all of the pieces together. We will post updates along the process that will include behind the scenes and Q&A with our director and lead actors.What We Need


1. This is a professional shoot which means we will be needing to rent top of the line lenses to ensure the best visual quality for our piece.

2. We will have to rent out locations in order for this world to come to life! 
3. Craft Services! A crew must be well feed and hydrated for the long hours we will be putting in. 
4. If we make more than our goal then we would like to continue the series. We have written what we call a series bible that entails all the following episodes in significant detail! 
-- This is a non-profit project. We are just trying to create a web-series for pure enjoyment for the viewers.
   
Other Ways You Can Help


 1. SHARE! Even if you cannot contribute to the fund, simply sharing our post to your friends will potentially bring in new viewers. 
We appreciate all the help and are excited to bring you something new and worth watching.

story:
What if there is so much more that we can't see?  What if that blank stare isn't as empty as it seems?  What if our final sanctuary is within one's own memories?  What if love can't be silenced?

Walk with me through The Origami Gate...


Like many families, mine had to endure the pain of watching a loved one suffer through dementia.  My grandmother slowly declined and eventually succumbed to the disease over the course of several years. And for anyone who has known someone with dementia or Alzheimer's, it is a frustrating and helpless ordeal... watching someone so full of life fade into unresponsive silence.  And while dementia affects so many people (around 36 million globally) and research continues to look at treatments and preventative measures, there is no cure.

So to that end, in honor of my grandmother and all of those who suffer from the disease, we are making this film to continue the discussion and raise attention and awareness for this condition which affects so many.  It is a story about love, meant to share a positive feeling with those who have suffered alongside their loved ones.



My name is Jeffrey Kraynak and I am a writer in New York City.  I've been writing for some time now, having penned ten features and seven shorts.  One of my shorts, Strive, won the Corporate Production competition for the Richmond International Film Festival and was subsequently produced and screened there.  A separate short won Best Screenplay at Richmond as well.  Several of my features have been accepted as official selections in numerous festivals internationally.  While screenwriting is my focus, I have also published a book of poetry (Animal Crackers) with my brother, who illustrated it.

Our main intention here is to just tell a great, heart-warming story.  And that's exactly what this is... though it's a little hard to explain without giving too much away.  As with much of my writing, things aren't always what they appear to be.  So let's talk inspiration.



Unfortunately, as I said before, my grandmother had dementia and my family and I had to watch her slowly decline over a span of several years.  And so I wondered how much of that silence was merely on the surface.  How many thoughts wanted to be expressed?  How many words ached for a voice to share them?  How much of a refuge did memories provide?  What if there was so much more going on behind those silent eyes?

So I wrote this piece about how love can bridge the most distant gaps.  As a writer and filmmaker, this is my way of sharing my own thoughts and experiences.  And hopefully, in doing so, it gives others with similar family experience something to connect with.


While this is a very personal passion project of mine, I can't do it alone.  In order to do this story justice, the only way is to do it right, and not cut any corners.  And that requires paying for the best.  While certain elements of this film I could probably do or get for free, I also believe in paying people for their work.  Here's a breakdown of our costs:

  • Location- We will be filming for two days at the gorgeous Bartow-Pell Mansion Museum in Pelham Bay, NY. It's one of our bigger expenses and necessary in order to give The Origami Gate its required elegance. $2000

  • Cast- We are working with an incredible group of SAG and Non-Union talent. These amazing professionals work from the heart and were naturally drawn to the story. $1900
  • Crew- These highly skilled technicians are also artists. The Rock Stars of a film set. $2850
  • Equipment- James is shooting on a Canon C300 with a super sweet kit. And Brandon doesn't work well without lights and stuff. $1200

                    

  • Post Production- We are hiring a Wizard... No, really, some very talented folks are making this film look and sound as beautiful as possible... I think they're wizards. $1200
  • Film Festival Submissions- Our intention is for The Origami gate to be widely viewed; to showcase our team of artists while at the same time raising awareness for Alzheimer's research and support groups. $400

                                    

  • Food- 14 people for two days and we all get very cranky without something to eat. $400
  • Insurance- Safety first, insurance second. $400
  • Transportation- Car and gas. $300
  • INDIEGOGO (4%)- Gladly given! $400
  • Credit Card fees (3%)- Their fair and proper. $300
We are a start-up Entertainment Company self-financing this production.  Your generous contributions will help bring this heartfelt story to life and get it out there to touch as many people as possible.

Be sure to check out the Updates section for cast interviews and behind the scenes footage!!!

CAST:

Bartek Szymanski's first role was "the boy" in his 5th grade play, "A Christmas Carol". He grew from that boy into a passionate and committed young actor. Studying theatre through high school at the Regional Center for the Arts in Trumbull, CT to constantly auditioning in NYC his senior year, Bartek is grateful to have worked on the many projects that he did. He currently studies BFA Acting for Film, Television, Voice-overs, and Commercials at Pace University.

After having graduated from NYU’s prestigious Tisch School of the Arts, Carole Ashley began her acting career in musical theatre. Her favorite credits include performing in and touring internationally with the Off-Broadway production of “Angelina Ballerina,” singing on the stages of Joe’s Pub, Union Square Theatre, and The Public Theatre and dancing in the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade alongside Andy Williams. Most recently, she’s decided to put her dancing shoes aside and follow her dream into a career in film, dedicating her time to study intensely with the brilliant acting teacher, Terry Schreiber.

Ralph Cashen started acting in plays in his home town on Cape Cod and moved to Los Angeles to pursue an education and career in film and theatre. He landed numerous theatre roles in Los Angeles and New York including leads in "Major Barbara" and "Proof."  As a versatile character actor and member of SAG, AFTRA,  and Actors' Equity, he can be seen in "The Whistler," as well as  "Seclusion" and "Violent Monday," both soon to be released.

Mary Looram has been acting in New York City since 2000. She can be seen as
"Celeste Chapman", grandmother of Piper Chapman, in the hit Series "Orange is the New Black". Mary has appeared in a number of independent films including Divergence, where she was acclaimed in its review in "Variety", in ABC's "What Would You Do?", and a number of appearances on David Letterman's "The Late Show". On stage in NYC, Mary has portrayed "Rebecca Nurse" in "The Crucible" as well as Best Supporting Actress in the production of "Day of The Dad".


CREW:

WRITER/DIRECTOR/PRODUCER - Jeffrey Kraynak

PRODUCER - Enrique Gonzalez

CINEMATOGRAPHY - James DuBourdieu

SOUND/BOOM OP - Matt Faso

GAFFER - Brandon Dottin

ASST CAMERA - Yale Goodman

MUSIC- Alec Gross


Even if you can't contribute to the campaign, you can still help us out.  Share a link to the page.  Spread the word about our campaign and our film.  Follow us on Twitter.

We appreciate anything you can do to help!

Thank you for the support!

story:
Carrot Rocker is a short film that chronicles the story of an old ex-bassist named Robbie.  The film opens with Robbie planting carrots in his yard, which has become a favorite activity for the former rocker.  Unexpectedly, Robbie receives a letter inviting him to an audition, though his band has been disbanded for many years.  The surprise invitation helps Robbie to realize that he wants to relive his time as a rocker, and to get back on stage where he belongs. His wife, Jan, thinks that Robbie is too old to chase old rock dreams and wants him to move on with his life.  Despite Jan’s reservations about the time commitment and his ability to get back his old prowess as a bassist, Robbie knows he has to make a decision. 

This short film was written by Hal Quincy (who, coincidently, used to be a rocker), and was co-written by Bryan Stubbles.  My name is David Yap and I’m the Director for this exciting project.  I had been searching for a story that could address the question "Can one get too old for their passion?"  After reading Carrot Rocker, I immediately fell in love with the story and simply had to be involved. 

We felt that it was essential to tell this story through a short film. The intention of using a short film to tell a story like this is that it permits the film to be unfathomably available, providing us with an energizing process to reach a more extensive crowd.  We trust that we can utilize this film to launch discussions and to further advance the importance of taking risks and grasping your enthusiasm, despite negativity or opposition. 

(Written in WriterDuet)


(We do not own this image, used as a representation/reference.)

As with all other films, we are in need of funds to produce the short, including staff, equipment, and promotion. We have invested our own hard-earned money to get the project started, but will need additional funding in order to keep it going.

Your contribution will help us to gather a skilled cast and crew, secure an excellent filming location, and to assemble the fundamental supplies necessary to make a film that is as outwardly dazzling and while effectively telling a story. 

The expenses.

  • More specialized Cast and Crew. 
  • Locations and insurance. (To make sure our head is protected)
  • Equipment. (Camera Rentals) 
  • Sound Guy. It doesn't matter how great your film looks, if it sounds like crap, it IS crap.
  • Post-production. Color correction, sound design, visual FX, music composition.
  • Marketing and distribution (Youth Film Festivals)

JUST ADDED!! Handwritten guitar pick. We will ship you a handwritten guitar pick at your doorstep. Let us know what you want us to write and the Director will sign the other side.  (20$ - A String Player Perk)


We hope that people will get the message that they should always chase their dreams, no matter what situation they find themselves in. You are never too old for something great in your life, and making that jump into the void could result in a life life filled with passion and excitement.

That being said, finding a crew and cast in Malaysia is a little difficult and often expensive to secure a good cast and crew, making the added expense difficult for an independent filmmaker.

That's why we've turned to IndieGoGo and to YOU to help us tell this story! Thanks to crowd funding, viewers now have a say as to what stories they believe are important to be told.

CARROT ROCKER strives to activate the inner passion of men or women who have a longing desire to achieve something great. 


By now, we hope that you're wondering how you can get involved and become part of CARROT ROCKER. Luckily for you, we're offering some great, affordable perks, including IMDB credits.

If you can't donate at this time, don't despair! There are still many ways to help us fund our project!  We would love for you to be a part of this voyage with us, in whatever way you can. Please share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and on any of your other favorite social media platforms. 

By helping us spread the word about CARROT ROCKER, you are making a huge contribution not only to this project, but also to the relevance of independent filmmaking. 

 


From the bottom of our hearts, thank you for joining our team and supporting this story. We look forward to share CARROT ROCKER with you.


What is the progress right now?

We are currently in the pre-production process. Pre-production is the period where we gather crews and cast to join our project. We have already secured the script and sent out an audition notice.

How many people is in the project right now?

We have a Producer, Co-Producer, Director, Asst. Director, Writer, and a Cinematographer. However, this list may expand as our campaign grows.

What is IMDB credit?

IMDB is a platform where all the information of motion picture is kept. IMDB stands for International Movie Database. Once you select a perk, let say an EXECUTIVE PRODUCER. Your name will be under the movie section "EXECUTIVE PRODUCER."  You’ll instantly get your own IMDB account, and will be visible to everyone from film fans to major motion picture directors. 

More Question?

ASK ME ANYTHING HERE!!


WORKING FILM POSTER
